**z-test**
- used as a [[Topics/Mathematics/Statistics and probabilities/Statistics/statistical tests|statistical tests]] for [[Topics/Mathematics/Statistics and probabilities/Statistics/Hypothesis testing|hypothesis testing]]
	- when distribution of the data is **normal** and independent (with a mean & a variance/standard deviation)
- it dates from the 19th century ?
- used when the sample is at minimum **more than 30**, or else use Student's [[Topics/Mathematics/Statistics and probabilities/Statistics/t-test|t-test]]
- part of **z tests** (a general class of tests statistic which use the normal distribution, aka. z-distribution)
- ==the z-test is **rarely used in practice**==, as the population deviation $\sigma$ is difficult to determine
- one tailed / two tailed "versions"
	- to test whether the mean is greater or less than a $\mu_0$ / or different from a $\mu_0$
- the value of $z$ correspond to a $p$-value (or an other approach to get **a critical value**)

### Z-score
- aka. standard score, or z-statistic (?)
- measures how many standard deviation above/below the population mean a **raw score** is
- to calculate it we must know the mean and the population standard deviation $\sigma$
- $\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}$ = standard error (SE) of the sample mean
- *==formulas==*
	- one sample : $z_i=\frac{x_i-\overline{x}}{s}$
	- **single sample z-test for means** : to check if the sample is drawn from a population *with known mean & variance*
		- $z \text{ score}=\frac{M-\mu}{\sqrt{\sigma^2/n}}$ or $\frac{M-\mu}{\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}}$, $M$ : the sample mean, $n$ : sample size, $\sigma$ : population std
		- it is a "location test" (?)
	- **two sample z-test for means**
		- appropriate to **compare 2 sample's means** => to see if it's possible they comes from the same population or if there is a statistically significant difference
		- but **rarely used** as both $\sigma$ are not often known => use sample standard deviation or t-distribution (?)
	- one-sample for proportions
	- two-sample for proportions
- a **z-table** is used to convert between z-score and a p-value => [z-table.com](http://www.z-table.com/)

![Pasted image 20220212111032.png](data:image/png;base64,)

### Reminder/associated notes
- [[Topics/Mathematics/Statistics and probabilities/Statistics/p-value|p-value]] (probability value) : smallest significance level
	- It's the probability to get the value or a more extrem value than the one observed
	- permit to reject or not the null hypothesis
